items.title: Awakening of the Abyss
items.summary: Awakening of the Abyss is a video game project developed from scratch…
items.content_html:
Awakening of the Abyss is a video game project developed from scratch by a team of five students. The project was an opportunity to approach Unreal Engine for the first time, allowing me to become familiar with its interface, workflow, and technical management. I also explored programming through Blueprints, creating simple in-game interactions and understanding the logic behind real-time systems. As the team leader, I coordinated the group’s workflow and communication, ensuring consistency and efficiency throughout development. My main responsibilities included 3D modeling, texturing, and, above all, the technical management of Unreal Engine, handling project organization, scene setup, and optimization.

his experience was extremely valuable in improving my teamwork, problem-solving, and leadership skills, while deepening my understanding of the technical side of game production within Unreal Engine.

 
 
 

 

Game overview

 

A long tima ago, on a dry, lifeless world, living beings fought to survive. Moved by compassion, a mysterious Goddess of Water descended from the heavens, bringing water, and through it, life, to the planet’s dying inhabitants.
But her act of mercy defied the laws of the ancient Gods. In their fury, they cursed and banished her to the depths of the very oceans she had created, tturning her into stone and imprisoning her in an underwater temple.
Generations later, legends tell of a Chosen One destined to overcome three great trials and defeat the creature guarding her underwater tomb, to finally break the curse.

 
 

The game world is made up of nine unique areas that the player explores, interacting and performing actions controlled through Blueprint scripting in Unreal Engine:

The library

The library

An old classical library, renowned for its vast collection of books and centuries-old manuscripts. Red carpets lie upon the wooden floors, guiding visitors toward small alcoves filled with stacks of books, documents, and maps. Sunlight filters through colorful stained-glass windows, illuminating the grand central bookcase, a structure shrouded in mystery and history.


The cave

The cave

Beneath the library lies an ancient, towering cave a mysterious space formed between two tectonic plates deep under the sea. Legends tell that it was created by the impact of an ancient deity who once aided humankind and was punished by the Gods, turned to stone, and cast into the ocean’s depths. Her devoted followers later built a temple within the cave, to guard what remained of their sacred, petrified Goddess.

 

The hall of rebirth

The hall of rebirth

Hidden within the temple lies the first chamber, where the devotees of the Goddess gather. This sacred hall, marked by towering columns and a glowing dome, reflects the flowing shapes of the sea, almost becoming one with it. Gentle light filters through the lantern above, revealing glimpses of the ocean life outside. Here begins the First Trial: those who wish to free the Goddess must drink from the poisoned spring, an act of faith that marks the start of their journey.

 

 


The ancient corridor

The ancient corridor

An ancient corridor leads to the sacred hall that houses the statue of the deity. The organically shaped columns rise and merge seamlessly with the ceiling, as in the baptistery and the statue chamber, creating a harmonious blend between the architecture of a classical church and the atmosphere of an underwater cave. Between each column, gentle waterfalls allow the sea to flow into the passage, bringing motion and life to the sacred space.

 

The hall of the Goddess

The hall of the Goddess

The largest chamber of the temple, where the remnants of the Goddess are kept. Fish swim in the large side pools that support the columns and the structure of the entire room. At the back stands an altar, meant to hold the three talismans placed by the chosen one. On each side, stairways emerge from the water, leading to the rooms where the different trials take place. The ceiling features a large spiral shape, similar to a marine vortex and reminiscent of the baptistery’s design, but on a much larger scale.

 

 


The chess hall

The chess hall

The first trial takes place here, upon a vast chessboard at the center of the room. The initiate must solve the puzzle and move the pieces correctly to reveal the ancient passages leading to the long-forgotten prisons of traitors. A stained-glass window bathes the hall in colored light, reflecting across stone and water. Among the temple’s oldest chambers, it feels more like a living cave than a constructed space. In the upper levels, the last initiate who dared to defy the temple remains bound in chains.

 

 

The prison

The prison

The darkest and most somber chamber of the temple, where those who once posed as adepts, but were in truth envoys or persecutors of the Goddess, were imprisoned for trying to destroy the adepts’ sacred work. The room is a labyrinth of shadows, lit only by blue-flamed torches and the faint glow of spirits trapped within hanging skulls. Each cell is filled with sand and bones, and on the walls lie hidden ancient seals, visible only to the chosen one.

 

 


The mortuary chamber

The mortuary chamber

At first glance, this room appears more welcoming, lit by the warm glow of torches and the soft light of the sea filtering through stained-glass panels in the ceiling. It was also among the temple’s earliest constructions, once home to the last of the elder adepts who escaped the wrath of the Gods. This chamber served both as the study of the wise elder and as the resting place for those who perished within the ancient temple.

 

 

The monster's pit

The monster's pit

A deep pit lies beneath the Hall of the Deity, home to the giant parasite sent by the Gods when they discovered the adepts’ attempt to preserve the statue and lift its curse. Narrow, suffocating steps descend into this vast abyss. Over time, seawater filled the pit, submerging the creature and allowing it to breathe. Born without eyes, the monster was granted sight by the Gods through enormous eyes embedded in the walls, letting it sense anyone who dares to descend into its domain.

items.title: Robot
items.summary: In this project, I focused on modeling and texturing a highly realistic…
items.content_html:
In this project, I focused on modeling and texturing a highly realistic robot, which was then integrated into live-action footage using Nuke. The work allowed me to refine my hard-surface modeling skills, an area I particularly enjoy, and to enhance my texturing techniques through Substance Painter.

also also developed my skilles in compositing, blending 3D renders with real-world footage to ensure accurate lighting, reflections, and shadows. Working on this project gave me the chance to follow a full cinematic pipeline, from initial asset creation to final integration, reinforcing my understanding of professional workflows.

 

 
 
 
 
 
 

The project focused on hard-surface modeling in Maya, aimed at achieving precise geometry and clean topology for a realistic robotic design. Substance 3D Painter was employed to develop textures across multiple UDIMs, following a PBR workflow.

items.title: Pop Tale
items.summary: Pop Tale is a group thesis project developed over almost a year…
items.content_html:
Pop Tale is a group thesis project developed over almost a year by a team of six students. This animated short film gave me the opportunity to grow both technically and personally, working within a complete production pipeline from concept to final render. My main responsibilities included VFX, rendering and compositing, but I also provided support in 3D modeling, contributing to the creation of assets and environments.

Beyond the technical aspects, Pop Tale was a formative experience in teamwork, communication, and problem-solving, helping me develop a collaborative mindset and the ability to adapt to creative and technical challenges throughout production.

 

 

Project overview

 

What if the solution to your problems came from a commercial? How likely would it be a scam? Chester Wyatt never really asked himself that question… or maybe he did, just a little too late. Chester, a lazy and disorganized farmer,  suddenly finds himself caught in a challenge far beyond his abilities: turning his long-neglected cornfield into the best in the county, all to win a tempting cash prize. And he has less than twenty-four hours to do it. A hopeless task… or maybe there’s still a chance.
Pop Tale was born from the clear intention to create something genuinely fun, a story capable of making people smile while drawing them into a carefully crafted world. From this simple yet effective idea began our creative adventure: a challenge to ourselves, a long and meticulous journey built on artistic research and strong teamwork. Every visual choice, every animation, every detail of the environments and characters was the result of collective discussion, sometimes heated, but always constructive.

 

CHARACTERS

Chester Wyatt (The Farmer)

Chester Wyatt (The Farmer)

From the very early stages of development, the farmer was conceived as a comedic character. The main challenge was defining what kind of humor he should embody: after several considerations, he was ultimately designed as a naive and clumsy figure, more distinctive and spontaneous than the classic grumpy farmer archetype. These traits are reflected in his appearance: a pronounced nose, drooping eyes, and a slightly goofy smile with two protruding teeth and a perpetually distracted expression. He is tall and slim, yet slightly hunched and unkempt, with slow, uncoordinated movements that emphasize his lazy demeanor. His color palette and outfit complete his personality: a faded, oversized denim overall, a white shirt with orange details, and an old, worn-out hat.


Reginald Tucker Carrington Montgomery (The Mayor)

Reginald Tucker Carrington Montgomery (The Mayor)

In designing the mayor’s character, the goal was to create a clear contrast with the farmer, both physically and in personality, to make their dynamic immediately recognizable.
The mayor is short, stocky, and stiff in his movements, with a formal and authoritative attitude that contrasts sharply with the farmer’s spontaneous clumsiness. He is proud, serious, and convinced of his own importance, but this excessive composure makes him comical, as reality constantly undercuts his self-image.
Visually, he stands out through his neat clothing and cool-toned color palette (magenta, purple, and blue), in opposition to the warm tones of the rural characters. This visually isolates him from his surroundings, emphasizing his out-of-place nature.
The mayor thus embodies the archetype of the overly serious character who, without meaning to, becomes ridiculous—perfectly contributing to the short film’s ironic and surreal tone.

 

Cornelius Wyatt The IV (The Chicken)

Cornelius Wyatt The IV
(The Chicken)

The creation of the chicken character, Cornelius, was one of the most stimulating challenges of the project. The goal was to combine his narrative purpose with strong comedic potential, making him the farmer’s comic sidekick. After studying various chicken breeds, the team chose a design that balanced agility and clumsiness, reflecting his dual nature: naive and awkward, yet clever and observant.
Physically, Cornelius has a compact, rounded build, perfect for physical gags, yet still agile. His warm color palette makes him lively and instantly recognizable.
The character was modeled in Maya and sculpted in ZBrush, with special attention to detail and the needs of the rigger. During the texturing phase, bold color gradients were tested. Cornelius ultimately became a key element of the short film, bringing energy, humor, and rhythm to the story.

 

 

ENVIRONMENTS

Living room

Living room

The living room appears as a chaotic space, filled with eccentric items and knick-knacks that perfectly reflect the protagonist’s personality. Among the details, there are posters that reveal his musical passions, quirky objects such as a rubber chicken, a SNES console used during his leisure time, and numerous items scattered out of place.
From a technical perspective, the scene features intentionally stylized forms in the main pieces of furniture, such as the armchair, the cabinet, and the television, complemented by secondary objects, including a remote control, a stove, and a gramophone in the background.


Desk

Desk

The desk serves as the protagonist’s command center, the place where all his passions and obsessions come together. Among them stand out baseball, but above all, his fixation with aliens.
On the wall behind him hangs a bulletin board filled with photographs, clues, and newspaper clippings about UFO sightings, undeniable evidence of the existence of extraterrestrial beings.
A particularly striking detail is the computer: an old case held together with duct tape, powered by a car battery, and topped with an improvised antenna in a desperate attempt to pick up a signal.

 

Kitchen

Kitchen

Bathed in the warm light of the morning sun, the kitchen initially conveys a sense of calm and comfort — the perfect setting for a quiet breakfast. Yet, a closer look reveals the unmistakable touch of the protagonist and his chaotic lifestyle: socks stuffed into pots, a sink overflowing with dirty dishes, scattered utensils, grimy rags draped carelessly around, and even a sausage poking out of the refrigerator.
Despite the mess, this cluttered environment perfectly mirrors his eccentric personality, turning disorder into character. Adding a humorous twist, a bowl of chicken feed sits on the floor with a handwritten sign reading “Corny food” — a playful detail that reinforces the quirky charm of the space and the ever-present hint of absurdity that defines the protagonist’s world.

Entrance

Entrance

The entrance, bathed in sunlight that cuts dramatically across the scene, welcomes the viewer with a warm and lively atmosphere. The staircase immediately draws attention with a wall completely covered in framed pictures, each one telling a small part of the protagonists’ story. At the heart of the scene stands the main door with a tiny door just for the chicken.


Bedroom

Bedroom

The bedroom is a small, intimate space where some of the story’s most meaningful elements come together. On the protagonist’s nightstand rests the nest of his inseparable pet, who insists on sleeping close to its owner despite knowing what awaits each morning: becoming his “living alarm clock,” with all the inevitable consequences of trying to wake someone lazy.


Exterior

Exterior

The exterior setting of the short film portrays a quiet American farmhouse, with the protagonist’s home at its center, a structure designed to mirror his personality. The surrounding details bring the scene to life: a small chicken coop, a mailbox topped with an antenna and covered in alien stickers, and rustic touches like barrels, hay bales, and wooden fences.
Completing this quirky setting is the farmer’s stall, a small, improvised structure built from reused materials. With a faded beach umbrella, an old mini fridge, and a rusty bicycle, it gives off a feeling of creative messiness.
